content.p: Referred pain is a phenomenon where visceral pain receptors share a common dorsal root into spinal cord with sensory receptors from the skin. As a result, the brain misinterprets the source of the pain as coming from the more commonly stimulated dermal region, rather than the internal organ. Understanding the dermatome map can help explain why certain diseases are “felt” in other parts of the body.

body.p: Pain receptors associated with heart muscle enter the spinal cord in dorsal roots of spinal nerves T1 to T4. Where would a person “feel” the pain from myocardial ischemia (heart attack)?

multiple_choice.choice: the middle of chest where the heart is located
upper chest and radiating along the arm to the hand

feedback.p: Incorrect. This would involve cervical spinal nerves.
Incorrect. The brain is not interpreting the pain sensation as coming directly from the visceral organ.
Correct. The skin from these areas shares the same dorsal root with these heart nociceptors, resulting in the referred pain sensations.
Incorrect. This would have to involve the lower thoracic spinal nerves .
Incorrect. This would have to involve the lumbar spinal nerves.

hint.p: Look at the dermatome map to determine the location of referred pain perception due to the somatic and visceral receptors sharing the same dorsal root pathway.

body.p: The phrenic nerve that serves the diaphragm arises from spinal nerves C3 & C4. As a result, problems with organs directly above or below the diaphragm can stimulate the pain receptors associated with the diaphragm. Where would a person with liver disease, gallstones or pneumonia possibly feel referred pain?

multiple_choice.choice: middle of the chest where the organs are
upper chest and radiating along the arm to the hand

feedback.p: Correct. Sometimes the first sign of this problem is mistaken as a muscle pain in the shoulder or neck attributed to sleep position or or the result of shoulder exercises.
Incorrect. The brain is not interpreting the pain sensation as coming directly from the visceral organ.
Incorrect. This would have to involve the upper thoracic spinal nerves.
Incorrect. This would have to involve the lower thoracic spinal nerves.
Incorrect. This would have to involve the lumbar spinal nerves.

hint.p: Look at the dermatome map to determine the location of referred pain perception due to the somatic and visceral receptors sharing the same dorsal root pathway.

body.p: The “brain freeze” headache (seemingly from the forehead or behind the eyes) that sometimes develops after rapidly eating ice cream, involves referred pain along what cranial nerve?

feedback.p: Incorrect. This would mean the pain was referred to the retina of the eye.
Incorrect. This would mean the pain was referred to the nasal conchae area.
Correct. The trigeminal serves the dermatome of the facial skin, so the pain is felt there.
Incorrect. This would mean the pain was referred to muscle that moves the eye, not the forehead and area behind the eyes.
